s1: Cyber Security Foundations introduces all essential cyber security principles.
s2: Knowledge, practices and tools considered in this course will include process models, requirements engineering, design, modelling and user experience.

s1: This includes principles of secure design, secrets minimization, least privilege, isolation, separation and encapsulation.
s2: We will use real-world examples such as distributed, high-integrity, web-based systems where rigorous software engineering can demonstrably enhance business value.

s1: The interplay between failed security principles and vulnerabilities is investigated in detail.
s2: We will use real-world examples such as distributed, high-integrity, web-based systems where rigorous software engineering can demonstrably enhance business value.

s1: The course provides the essential foundations which allow students to continue in a more in-depth cyber security career, yet can also be used a standalone unit to provide a self-contained set of knowledge.
s2: This course will empower students with the ability and confidence necessary to exercise critical thinking and professional judgment to select and apply appropriate knowledge, practices and tools to the development of non-trivial software systems.

s1: Demonstrate a thorough understanding of the fundamental principles underlying Cyber Security.
s2: We will build on previous programming courses to deepen and broaden students' knowledge and understanding of the practices and tools used to build large software systems within complex environments.

s1: Define and identify cyber security principles and their violation.

s2: We will use real-world examples such as distributed, high-integrity, web-based systems where rigorous software engineering can demonstrably enhance business value.

s1: Migrate insights from cyber security analysis into new designs.
